article.paragraph: Amotor neuron disease(MND) is any of fiveneurological disordersthat selectively affectmotor neurons, the cells that controlvoluntary musclesof the body. These five conditions areamyotrophic lateral sclerosis,primary lateral sclerosis,progressive muscular atrophy,progressive bulbar palsyandpseudobulbar palsy.cite webhttp://www.ninds.nih.gov/disorders/motor_neuron_diseases/detail_motor_neuron_diseases.htmMotor Neuron Diseases Fact Sheet: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke (NINDS)www.ninds.nih.gov7 November 2010They areneurodegenerativein nature and cause increasing disability and, eventually, death.
article.heading: Terminology

preblock.preline: Technically the term "motor neuron disease" includes five diseases:amyotrophic lateral sclerosis(ALS),primary lateral sclerosis,progressive muscular atrophy,progressive bulbar palsyandpseudobulbar palsy.cite webhttp://www.ninds.nih.gov/disorders/motor_neuron_diseases/detail_motor_neuron_diseases.htmMotor Neuron Diseases Fact Sheet: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke (NINDS)www.ninds.nih.gov7 November 2010

article.paragraph: In the United States the term is often used interchangeably with ALS.In the United Kingdom "motor neurone disease" may be used to mean ALS.

While MND refers to a specific subset of similar diseases, there are numerous other diseases ofmotor neuronsthat are referred to collectively as "motor neuron disorders", for instance disease belonging tospinal muscular atrophies.cite bookEllisonedited by Seth Love, David N. Louis, David W.Greenfield's neuropathology2008Hodder ArnoldLondon97803409068119478thhttp://books.google.ca/books?idHowever, they are not classified as "motor neuron diseases" by theICD-10tenth International Statistical Classification of Diseases and Related Health Problems(ICD-10) which is the definition followed in this article.
